Introduction

Clostridial myonecrosis, also known as gas gangrene, is a rapidly progressive and potentially fatal infection caused by bacteria of the genus Clostridium.  Traumatic cases typically occur due to Clostridium perfringens.  Spontaneous cases (which usually spread hematogenously from gastrointestinal tract pathology) typically result from C septicum.  These bacteria are spore-forming and anaerobic (thrive in the absence of oxygen) and produce potent toxins that cause extensive muscle tissue death (necrosis) and gas production.

Pathophysiology

The development of clostridial myonecrosis depends on the convergence of 2 critical factors:

  • Tissue hypoxia:  Low oxygen availability in muscle tissue creates an environment conducive to clostridial growth.  This can occur due to trauma with significant blood flow disruption, vascular insufficiency, or surgical complications (eg, hematoma, seroma).
  • Contamination with clostridia:  Clostridium spores are ubiquitous in the environment, particularly soil and the human gastrointestinal tract.  Traumatic gas gangrene develops in wounds contaminated with spores, especially deep wounds or those with devitalized tissue, which provide a suitable environment for germination and bacterial proliferation.  Spontaneous gas gangrene occurs due to muscle seeding from the gastrointestinal tract.

Once established in the hypoxic environment, clostridia produce a complex array of toxins, including the following:

  • Alpha toxin:  a potent phospholipase C mimetic that splits host phospholipids.  It hydrolyzes lecithin-containing lipoprotein complexes in cell membranes, which causes cell lysis, tissue necrosis, and edema.  It mediates intravascular aggregations of platelets, neutrophils, and fibrin, resulting in vascular occlusion and further promoting the anaerobic environment required for bacterial proliferation.  The phospholipase C mimetic is also believed to be responsible for a reduction in polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) ability to cross the endothelial cell barrier into infected tissue.
  • Theta toxin:  directly lyses muscle cells, leading to tissue necrosis and further compromise of blood flow; it also blunts host inflammatory response.
  • Collagenases:  degrade connective tissue, facilitating the spread of infection.

Gas production, a hallmark feature of clostridial myonecrosis, is a consequence of bacterial fermentation processes.  Hydrogen gas distends tissue, further impeding blood flow and creating a vicious cycle of tissue death.

Risk factors

  • Traumatic injuries:  Patients with open wounds, particularly those with devitalized tissue and contaminated with soil or feces, are at high risk.
  • Surgery:  Postoperative complications such as hematoma formation or seroma can create a suitable environment for clostridial growth.
  • Crush injuries:  Extensive tissue damage and impaired blood flow can predispose to clostridial infection.
  • Diabetic ulcers:  Chronic wounds with poor blood supply are susceptible to clostridial colonization.
  • Immunosuppression:  Individuals with weakened immune systems are more vulnerable to infection.
  • Intravenous drug use:  Contaminated injection sites can introduce clostridia into the body.

Pathology

Macroscopic examination of affected muscle tissue reveals extensive necrosis, often with a characteristic greenish-black discoloration due to myoglobin breakdown products (

image 1
).  Gas bubbles are typically present, and the tissue is foul-smelling.  Microscopic examination demonstrates widespread muscle fiber necrosis.  PMNs are absent from infected tissue but are present along the endothelium of small blood vessels (eg, capillaries, arterioles, postcapillary venules).  This differs from other soft-tissue infections (eg, Staphylococcus aureus) in which PMNs are present in the infected tissue.

Clinical presentation

The clinical presentation of clostridial myonecrosis progresses rapidly.  Early manifestations include:

  • Severe pain at the wound site, often out of proportion to the visible injury
  • Rapidly developing swelling and edema

As the infection progresses, additional features may include:

  • Bronze or dusky discoloration of the skin
  • Blisters filled with bloody fluid (bullae)
  • Crepitus (a crackling sensation on palpation due to gas in the tissues)
  • Fever, chills, and malaise
  • Systemic signs (eg, sepsis, hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status)

Diagnostic evaluation

Laboratory testing may reveal the following:

  • Elevated white blood cell count, a marker of inflammation
  • Electrolyte imbalances, a consequence of tissue breakdown
  • Abnormal kidney and liver function tests in severe cases

Imaging studies play an important role in identifying the extent of tissue involvement and gas presence.

  • Plain radiographs:  X-rays may show gas within the affected muscle tissue.
  • CT scan:  provides detailed cross-sectional views of the affected area and can be more sensitive for detecting gas than plain radiographs.
  • MRI scan:  Although less commonly used, it can be helpful in differentiating CM from other soft- tissue infections.

A high index of suspicion is important for timely diagnosis.  The diagnosis should be considered in any patient with fever and severe pain in the appropriate clinical setting (eg, trauma, colonic malignancy).  Ancillary features (eg, crepitus, abnormal laboratory testing, imaging with gas within tissue) can be suggestive, but a definitive diagnosis can be made only when large gram-variable rods are identified at the affected site.

Differential diagnosis

  • Necrotizing fasciitis (

    ):  is a rapidly progressive bacterial infection that also causes extensive tissue necrosis.  However, the causative organisms are typically different (eg, Streptococcus and Staphylococcus species), and soft-tissue gas is present in only about half of cases.
  • Cellulitis:  is a bacterial skin infection that can cause swelling and localized redness but typically does not involve deep-tissue necrosis or cause gas production; systemic symptoms (eg, fever, sepsis) are less common.
  • Acute limb ischemia:  causes sudden pain and diminished or absent perfusion to a limb.  CT angiography shows decreased or absent blood flow.  Soft-tissue gas and systemic symptoms (eg, fever, hypotension) are not expected.
  • Rhabdomyolysis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  has a variety of causes (eg, trauma, medication, metabolic disorders) and can result in significant muscle pain.  Gas is not present on imaging and Gram stain reveals no organisms.
  • Vibrio vulnificus wound infection:  can cause cellulitis with fluid-filled bullae; overwhelming sepsis can also occur.  In contrast to clostridial infections, which typically result from exposure to contaminated soil, Vibrio infections occur after exposure to sea water (eg, via a wound, ingestion of contaminated shellfish).  Gram stain reveals gram-negative rods.

Management

Prompt and aggressive intervention is essential to improve outcomes in clostridial myonecrosis.  Management requires early surgical debridement and antibiotic therapy.

  • Surgical debridement:  Aggressive surgical removal of all necrotic and devitalized tissue is paramount to limit toxin production and bacterial spread.  This may involve multiple surgeries as demarcation between viable and nonviable tissue becomes clearer.
  • Antibiotic therapy:
    • Initially, broad-spectrum antibiotics (eg, piperacillin-tazobactam plus clindamycin) are administered intravenously to cover group A Streptococcus, Clostridium species, and mixed aerobes and anaerobes.
    • When C perfringens or C septicum infection is confirmed, penicillin plus clindamycin (or tetracycline when C perfringens is the culprit organism) is a preferred regimen.  The specific antibiotic regimen may be adjusted based on culture and sensitivity results.

Another potentially beneficial therapy is hyperbaric oxygen therapy.  Exposure to high-pressure oxygen can inhibit clostridial growth, enhance antibiotic delivery to affected tissues, and promote wound healing.

Complications

The rapid progression of CM can lead to severe complications, including:

  • Compartment syndrome:  Increased tissue pressure within a confined fascial space can compromise blood flow and lead to further tissue necrosis.  Emergency fasciotomy, a surgical procedure to relieve pressure, may be necessary.
  • Sepsis:  Release of bacterial toxins into the bloodstream can trigger a life-threatening systemic inflammatory response.
  • Intravascular hemolysis:  This condition is likely caused by both alpha and theta toxins.  Hemoglobin can drop precipitously.
  • Acute kidney injury:  Myoglobin breakdown products and hypotension can lead to kidney failure.  Toxins may directly damage renal tubular cells.
  • Respiratory failure:  In severe cases, sepsis and organ dysfunction can lead to respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.
  • Amputation:  Extensive tissue necrosis may necessitate limb amputation to control the infection and prevent death.

Prognosis

Clostridial myonecrosis has a high mortality rate (10%-40%).  Early diagnosis, prompt surgical debridement, and appropriate antibiotic therapy are critical for improving the chances of survival.  Delays in treatment significantly worsen the prognosis.  Residual functional limitations and chronic pain can occur in affected patients who survive the infection.

Summary

Clostridial myonecrosis is a rapidly progressive and potentially life-threatening infection caused by bacteria of the genus Clostridium.  Pain out of proportion to examination and soft-tissue gas are hallmarks of the disease.  A high index of suspicion, prompt diagnosis, and aggressive surgical debridement combined with antibiotic therapy are essential for optimal outcomes.
